text: Commitment to Transfer. ERIC Digest.
label: H4

text: THIS DIGEST WAS CREATED BY ERIC, THE EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES
label: BODY

text: INFORMATION CENTER. FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ERIC, CONTACT
label: BODY

text: ACCESS ERIC 1-800-LET-ERIC
label: BODY

text: The community colleges have had a commitment to transfer since their beginnings. One
label: BODY

text: of their initial purposes was to take students from secondary school, provide them with
label: BODY

text: general education and introductory collegiate studies, and send them on to senior
label: BODY

text: institutions for the baccalaureate. An associate degree recipient was presumed to be
label: BODY

text: qualified to enter the junior year at a university. The associate in arts and associate in
label: BODY

text: ED310832 1989-08-00 Commitment to Transfer. ERIC Digest.
label: BODY

text: Page 1 of 6
label: BODY

text: www.eric.ed.gov
label: BODY

text: ERIC Custom Transformations Team
label: BODY

text: science have always been viewed as preparatory; the few associate degrees that were
label: BODY

text: not designed for transfer were given titles such as associate in applied science or
label: BODY

text: associate in general studies.
label: BODY

text: SHIFTING PRIORITIES
label: H4

text: Accusations that the community colleges do not prepare their students sufficiently well
label: BODY

text: for transfer have arisen because the proportion of students entering the colleges with
label: BODY

text: the intention of transferring and the proportion of those who did in fact transfer dropped
label: BODY

text: notably during the 1970s and early 1980s. According to Medsker (1960), two-thirds of
label: BODY

text: the students entering community colleges in the 1950s sought transfer. By the 1980s,
label: BODY

text: that proportion had dropped to one-third. Around one-third of the students actually
label: BODY

text: transferred in the 1960s. Twenty years later that proportion had dropped to under 15
label: BODY

text: percent.
label: BODY

text: Patterns of student attendance also reveal shifting priorities. The community colleges
label: BODY

text: enroll 37 percent of all students attending higher education in America and, 48 percent
label: BODY

text: of all the undergraduates. However, 65 percent of the community college students
label: BODY

text: attend part time (Fernandez, 1987) and many already have college degrees. Some
label: BODY

text: college district figures reflect this differentiated pattern of student attendance. Among
label: BODY

text: the Maricopa Community College District's 60,000 students, 7,000 were formerly
label: BODY

text: enrolled in Arizona State University, whereas 8,700 Arizona State University students
label: BODY

text: were formerly enrolled in the Maricopa colleges. Furthermore, although 45 percent of
label: BODY

text: the high-school graduates in the Phoenix metropolitan area enter one of the local
label: BODY

text: community colleges, they account for only 8 percent of the district's full-time equivalent
label: BODY

text: student enrollment (de los Santos, 1989).
label: BODY

text: INFLUENCES ON TRANSFER RATES
label: H4

text: There is no question that students enrolling in community colleges are somewhat less
label: BODY

text: likely than four-year college students to attain baccalaureate degrees within four or five
label: BODY

text: years. The part-time attendance pattern certainly accounts for some of the difference
label: BODY

text: between community college matriculants and those entering as freshmen in four-year
label: BODY

text: institutions. Since few community college students reside on campus or have
label: BODY

text: on-campus jobs, they tend to be less involved with their collegiate studies than their
label: BODY

text: four-year college counterparts.
label: BODY

text: The mere fact that community college matriculants must transfer from one institution to
label: BODY

text: another before obtaining the baccalaureate accounts for some of the shortfall. Many
label: BODY

text: things can happen in the process: students take jobs instead; they find that they cannot
label: BODY

text: readily leave their hometowns to go to the university; it becomes convenient to step out
label: BODY

text: of education for a while and get on with other aspects of their lives.
label: BODY

text: One of the widely held misconceptions about the reasons fewer students who begin
label: BODY

text: their college careers at community colleges obtain baccalaureate degrees is that the
label: BODY

text: Page 2 of 6
label: BODY

text: ED310832 1989-08-00 Commitment to Transfer. ERIC Digest.
label: BODY

text: ERIC Resource Center
label: BODY

text: www.eric.ed.gov
label: BODY

text: colleges emphasize occupational studies and courses that do not carry transfer credit.
label: BODY

text: However, more students transfer from so-called career programs than from the
label: BODY

text: traditional baccalaureate directed programs. Career education does not undermine
label: BODY

text: transfer from community colleges; rather, the transfer function is weakened by
label: BODY

text: institutional policies that support the idea of the college as a passive resource available
label: BODY

text: to all who would drop in at any time during their lifetimes to take a course in whatever
label: BODY

text: interests them at the time. These policies result in a lateral curriculum, one in which
label: BODY

text: prerequisites to courses are not enforced and in which student progress toward
label: BODY

text: program completion is not monitored.
label: BODY

text: The effects of such policies are revealed not only in the low rate of program completion,
label: BODY

text: but also in the high rate of student satisfaction. Although 85 percent of community
label: BODY

text: college students do not obtain degrees, a similar proportion say that the college
label: BODY

text: provided them with what they were looking for: courses for personal interest, access to
label: BODY

text: the job market, or studies basic to their becoming functionally literate. While the
label: BODY

text: organization and funding of community college instructional programs presuppose that
label: BODY

text: students are taking courses in order to complete an entire program, students are quite
label: BODY

text: satisfied with education short of the degree.
label: BODY

text: EFFORTS TO BOLSTER THE TRANSFER
label: H4

text: FUNCTION
label: H4

text: Many community colleges have attempted to increase their transfer rates by monitoring
label: BODY

text: student progress, providing information on transfer opportunities, enforcing course
label: BODY

text: prerequisites, holding special group meetings for prospective transfers, and similar
label: BODY

text: interventions. Remedial studies have become so prominent recently that they now
label: BODY

text: account for as much as one-third of the instructional budget, and represent the third
label: BODY

text: major function of the community colleges, behind only academic and occupational
label: BODY

text: studies. The colleges provide basic literacy studies for sizable proportions of their
label: BODY

text: students, including non-native English speakers, as well as those leaving high school
label: BODY

text: without the ability to read or write. Some of the most innovative instruction is done in the
label: BODY

text: remedial area.
label: BODY

text: Testing students at entry and again at the sophomore level has become prominent and
label: BODY

text: boasts to have an effect on the transfer figures. Colleges in several states are either
label: BODY

text: required or urged to test students at entry and place them in programs in which they
label: BODY

text: have a chance of success. That alone would account for much of the increase in
label: BODY

text: remedial work. Florida has had such a program for several years, and more recently a
label: BODY

text: requirement for basic skills assessment has been introduced into Texas. Rather than
label: BODY

text: mandating testing states such as California award additional monies to colleges that
label: BODY

text: impose matriculation tests and seek to augment their transfer-directed activities.
label: BODY

text: STATEWIDE EFFORTS
label: H4

text: ED310832 1989-08-00 Commitment to Transfer. ERIC Digest.
label: BODY

text: Page 3 of 6
label: BODY

text: www.eric.ed.gov
label: BODY

text: ERIC Custom Transformations Team
label: BODY

text: These special funds for transfer have become prominent. In 1987, eleven states were
label: BODY

text: making special monies available to colleges to enhance transfer-directed activities.
label: BODY

text: California set aside $3 million for transfer centers in 20 colleges. Colorado and Michigan
label: BODY

text: mandated articulation plans between community colleges and public universities. New
label: BODY

text: Jersey awarded special funds to its colleges to recruit transfer-oriented minority
label: BODY

text: students. Ohio awarded funds for colleges that would promote such activities (Center
label: BODY

text: for the Study of Community Colleges, 1987). Illinois had numerous special programs to
label: BODY

text: enhance minority student progress through the community colleges. These included
label: BODY

text: recruiting and counseling high school students, providing basic skills activities for adults,
label: BODY

text: and connecting the community colleges with elementary schools and intramural support
label: BODY

text: groups (Illinois Community College Board, 1989).
label: BODY

text: These types of transfer-directed activities have been summarized in many works
label: BODY

text: including those by Donovan and others (1987) and Richardson and Bender (1987).
label: BODY

text: Most of the interventions are well intentioned and will eventually have some effect.
label: BODY

text: However, some major changes must be made if the community colleges are to come
label: BODY

text: anywhere near parity in the proportion of their entering students who go on to receive
label: BODY

text: the baccalaureate. There should be statewide agreements to the effect that any student
label: BODY

text: who completes an associate degree program is guaranteed admission to the university
label: BODY

text: with no loss of credit. There should be special funds set aside for community colleges
label: BODY

text: that increase their percentage of transfers. Every state should have a centralized
label: BODY

text: student data base so that interinstitutional progress can be monitored. And there should
label: BODY

text: be common course numbering systems so that each student's transcript does not have
label: BODY

text: to be reviewed separately.
label: BODY

text: CONCLUSION
label: H4

text: Probably the most important single statement that can be made regarding student
label: BODY

text: transfer is that the community college staff members must identify the potential transfers
label: BODY

text: early on and monitor their progress through the colleges, making frequent direct contact
label: BODY

text: with them until they complete their studies and enter the universities. This takes a form
label: BODY

text: of dedication to student achievement that stands in contradistinction to the prevalent
label: BODY

text: laissez-faire approach to student attendance. The colleges cannot sit by and allow
label: BODY

text: students to take a random walk through the curriculum and at the same time expedite
label: BODY

text: student progress toward the baccalaureate.
label: BODY
